standard_metadata.standard_description: Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.

question.content: **Plot the image of triangle $\triangle ABC$ under a reflection across the $y$-axis.**

hints.content: A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[☃ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[☃ definition 2]], but on the other side.    [[☃ image 1]]  In other words, the line of reflection is the perpendicular bisector between any pair of corresponding points in the image and the pre-image.

images.alt: Point R is reflected across a line to form point R prime. Segment R R prime is perpendicular to the line.

hints.content: Since the $y$-axis is *vertical*, the reflection will move each point of $\triangle ABC$ *horizontally* across the axis.  For example, point $A$ is $2$ units to the right of the $y$-axis, so $A'$ will be $2$ units to the left of the axis.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C with point A at two, two, point B at two, four, and point C at five, three. A dashed arrow points from point A to point A prime at negative two, two.

hints.content: We can reflect each of the other vertices in the same way.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C with point A at two, two, point B at two, four, and point C at five, three. A dashed arrow points from point A to point A prime at negative two, two. A dashed arrow points from point B to point B prime at negative two, four. A dashed arrow points from point C to point C prime at negative five, three.

hints.content: This is the image of $\triangle ABC$ under the reflection.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C with point A at two, two, point B at two, four, and point C at five, three. The image formed is Triangle A prime B prime C prime with point A prime at negative two, two, point B prime at negative two, four, and point C prime at negative five, three.
